Slovenski ornamenti na vseh koncih sveta
Jože Karlovšek je bil raziskovalec in zbiralec stavbne dediščine in umetnostne obrti. Da izjemno zapuščino občudujejo celo v daljni Avstraliji, so poskrbeli njegovi potomci.
02 Nov 2019, 09:38 by Primož Hieng



Z ornamentom so polepšali lonček in džezvo. FOTO: osebni arhiv



Etnolog prof. dr. Janez Bogataj FOTO: Primož Hieng



Kozarce so izdelali v hrastniški steklarni. FOTO: osebni arhiv



Nakit z elementi Karlovškovega ornamenta FOTO: osebni arhiv



Avto Cvetko je preoblečen v ornamente. FOTO: osebni arhiv



Jože Karlovšek je bil med drugim stavbenik.



Katarina Karlovšek oživlja dedkove ornamente. FOTO: Primož Hieng


LJUBLJANA – Prihodnje leto bo minilo 120 let od rojstva Jožeta Karlovška, rojenega v Šmarjeti pri Novem mestu, ki je bil slovenski stavbenik, izumitelj ter neutrudni raziskovalec in zbiralec slovenske stavbne dediščine in umetnostne obrti. Izdal je več knjig o slovenski hiši in slovenskem ornamentu. Še danes velja, da je bil edini, ki je sistematično zbiral slovenske ornamente ter jih zapisoval in prerisoval. To je njegovo izjemno poslanstvo, da je vse ornamente, ki jih je našel, skrbno zabeležil in tudi raziskoval njihov izvor. Ti so zdaj odtisnjeni na skoraj 40 izdelkih.


Katarina Karlovšek oživlja dedkove ornamente. FOTO: Primož Hieng

Za vse to je poskrbela Katarina Karlovšek. Vnukinja dedka Jožeta žal ni poznala, saj je umrl 12 let pred njenim rojstvom. »Njegovo delo ali njegovo življenjsko pot je najbolj zaznamovala izjemna delavnost,« pravi Katarina. »V času svojega življenja je vzljubil vse, kar je bilo slovenskega. To so med drugim ornamenti, tipične slovenske hiše in detajli stavbne dediščine. Prav neverjetno je, kako je Jože Karlovšek že takrat čutil željo, da vse to, kar zaznamuje naš narod skozi našo kulturno dediščino, popiše, zapiše in to pusti nam, ki smo prišli za njim.«Del tega je verjetno tudi prenos Karlovškovih ornamentov na izdelke, ki imajo uporabno vrednost. »To je bila dolgoletna želja vseh družinskih članov, da ornamenti, ki so sicer zbrani v knjigah in so bili prikazani na številnih razstavah, pridejo med ljudi z določenimi predmeti, ki imajo praktično vrednost,« pove Katarina.
Zbiralec naše dediščine


Nakit z elementi Karlovškovega ornamenta FOTO: osebni arhiv

Nova kolekcija Slovenski ornament Jože Karlovšek nadaljuje njegovo delo in ohranja našo bogato kulturno dediščino slovenskega ornamenta. »Lani so v celjski Mohorjevi družbi izdali dnevnik branja za odrasle ter zvezek z motivom ornamenta Jožeta Karlovška,« še pove Katarina Karlovšek. »Podjetje Vivapen iz Celja je izdelalo nalivno pero, roler ter kaligrafska peresa z ornamentom. Podjetje Emo Celje je z ornamentom okrasilo lonček in džezvo, Steklarna Hrastnik pa je izdelala kozarce z ročno graviranim ornamentom. Slovenski etnografski muzej je napravil nakit z ornamentom. Del kolekcije so tudi ročno izdelane torbe ter ročno šivan nakit iz steklenih kroglic in swarovski kristalov. Kaligrafinja Katarina Rojc je izdelala voščilnico. V čokoladnici Lucifer so pripravili čokolado z okusom orehove potice, njeno embalažo pa krasi ornament. Vsi izdelki so kakovostne izdelave in slovenskega izvora. V nastajanju je damska ročna ura blagovne znamke Zlatarne Celje.«Spominek iz SlovenijeKarlovškova vnukinja Katarina pravi, da njo in širšo družino navdušuje dejstvo, kako ti ornamenti potujejo po svetu: »Zdaj jih s temi predmeti občudujejo celo v Avstraliji in Kanadi, kupujejo pa jih kot spominek iz Slovenije, na prodaj so v daljni Indiji. Delo Jožeta Karlovška dobiva novo poglavje, saj gre ta ornament zdaj po svetu. Ko ga pogledaš, ti v duši zaigra iskreno veselje.«Svoje mnenje je o delu Jožeta Karlovška in poslanstvu vnukinje Katarine zapisal etnolog prof. dr. Janez Bogataj: »Agencija RTA je obogatila trg poslovnih in protokolarnih daril, spominkov in uporabnih izdelkov s kolekcijo, kakršne pri nas še nismo poznali, tako v vsebinskem kot tudi aplikativnem razponu. Če rečemo aplikativnem, mislimo predvsem na t. i. slovenski ornament, ki naj bi pomagal sooblikovati razpoznavnost Slovenije z različnimi uporabnimi izdelki. Prizadevanja v tej smeri segajo sicer v 19. stoletje, vendar niso rodila trdnih in predvsem uspešnih sadov. Z vprašanji slovenskega ornamenta so se ukvarjali številni posamezniki, v glavnem ljubitelji. Najobsežnejši opus predstavlja zbirateljsko delo Jožeta Karlovška (1900–1963), sicer gradbenika, ki je čez 40 let marljivo zbiral po celotnem slovenskem ozemlju najrazličnejše gradivo z ornamenti.«


Etnolog prof. dr. Janez Bogataj FOTO: Primož Hieng

Že za časa svojega življenja je Jože Karlovšek glede ornamentike razvijal dvojnost, ki pa je ni ločeno obravnaval, pravi Bogataj: »Prvi mu je bil zbirateljski cilj, kar je tudi sicer značilnost vseh ljubiteljskih zbiralcev, drugi pa je bil bolj uporabne narave. S številnimi primeri je namreč poskušal prikazati uporabnost ornamentov in drugih krasilnih podrobnosti v novih njegovih kompozicijah, kot aplikacije na pohištvu, vezeninah, v stavbni opremi, raznih okrasnih predmetih in drugod. In prav v tej drugi dvojnosti se dediščina gradiva Jožeta Karlovška odlično sklada s kolekcijo Agencije RTA, ki ponuja paleto izdelkov s premišljeno apliciranimi ornamenti avtorja.«


Avto Cvetko je preoblečen v ornamente. FOTO: osebni arhiv

Ob ogledu zdaj že številnih izdelkov iz Karlovškove kolekcije bi kdo pomislil, da gre zgolj za kopiranje tega, kar je zbiratelj ustvaril. »Ne govorimo torej o ponavljanju zgodovinskega spomina ali zgolj kopiranju Karlovškovih ornamentov, ampak o premišljeni aplikaciji, ki upošteva različnost gradiv, oblike predmetov in njihove uporabnosti ter možne namene,« poudarja prof. dr. Bogataj. »S kolekcijo dobivamo v Sloveniji izdelke, ki so razpoznavni prav zaradi izbranih ornamentov. Ti niso na izdelke le nalepljeni, ampak so sestavni del celotnih struktur izdelkov. Lahko govorimo o lastnosti, ki jo je imela ornamentika že v obdobjih, ki nam danes predstavljajo kulturno dediščino.«

Slovenian ornaments in all corners of the globe
Jože Karlovšek was a researcher and collector of building heritage and crafts. His descendants have taken care of the remarkable legacy even in faraway Australia.
02 Nov 2019, 09:38 by Primoz Hieng



The ornament made the pot and jazz beautifying. PHOTO: Personal Archive



Ethnologist prof. dr. Janez Bogataj PHOTO: Primoz Hieng



The glasses were made in an oak glasshouse. PHOTO: Personal Archive



Jewelry with elements of Karlovšek's ornament PHOTO: personal archive



Cvetko's car is disguised as ornaments. PHOTO: Personal Archive



Jože Karlovsek was, among other things, a builder.



Katarina Karlovsek revives her grandfather's ornaments. PHOTO: Primoz Hieng


LJUBLJANA - Next year will mark 120 years since the birth of Jože Karlovšek, who was born in Šmarjeta near Novo mesto, who was a Slovenian builder, inventor and tireless researcher and collector of Slovenian heritage and crafts. He has published several books on Slovenian house and Slovenian ornament. Even today, he is considered to be the only one who systematically collected Slovenian ornaments and wrote and sketched them. It is his extraordinary mission to carefully record all the ornaments he finds and also to research their origins. These are now imprinted on nearly 40 products.


Katarina Karlovsek revives her grandfather's ornaments. PHOTO: Primoz Hieng

All this was taken care of by Katarina Karlovsek. Unfortunately, her grandfather Jože's granddaughter did not know since he died 12 years before she was born. "His work or his life was most marked by exceptional work," says Katarina. “During his life he loved everything that was Slovenian. These include ornaments, typical Slovenian houses and details of building heritage. It's amazing how even then Jože Karlovsek felt the urge to write down, write down everything that characterizes our nation through our cultural heritage, and leave it to us who came after him. ”Part of that is probably the transfer of Karlovsek's ornaments to products that have a useful value. "It has been the long-standing desire of all family members to have ornaments, which have been collected in books and shown in numerous exhibitions, to come among people with certain objects of practical value," says Katarina.
A collector of our heritage


Jewelry with elements of Karlovšek's ornament PHOTO: personal archive

New Slovenian Ornament Collection Jože Karlovšek continues his work and preserves our rich cultural heritage of Slovenian ornament. "Last year, the Celje Mohor Company published an adult reading diary and a notebook with the motif of Jože Karlovšek's ornament," says Katarina Karlovšek. »The Vivapen company from Celje made fountain pen, skateboard and calligraphic pens with ornament. The Emo Celje company decorated the pot and the jazz with the ornament, while Steklarna Hrastnik made the glasses with hand engraved ornament. The Slovenian Ethnographic Museum has made jewelry with ornament. The collection also includes handmade bags and hand-sewn jewelry made of glass beads and swarovski crystals. Calligrapher Katarina Rojc created a greeting card. The Lucifer chocolate bar has a nutty chocolate flavored chocolate and its packaging is ornamented. All products are of good quality and of Slovenian origin. A lady's wristwatch from the Zlatarna Celje brand is in the making. "A souvenir from SloveniaKarlovsk's granddaughter Katarina says that she and her extended family are impressed by the fact that these ornaments travel around the world:" Now they are admired by these items even in Australia and Canada and are being bought by as a souvenir from Slovenia, for sale in far India. The work of Jože Karlovšek is getting a new chapter, as this ornament is now going around the world. When you look at it, it gives you genuine joy in your soul. ”Ethnologist Prof. Prof. dr. dr. Janez Bogataj: “The RTA agency has enriched the market of business and protocol gifts, souvenirs and useful products with a collection that we did not know before, both in content and application range. When applied, we mean mainly t. i. Slovenian ornament intended to help shape Slovenia's distinctiveness with various useful products. Efforts in this direction go back to the 19th century, but they did not produce solid and, above all, successful fruits. A number of individuals, mainly lovers, have dealt with the issues of the Slovenian ornament. The most comprehensive oeuvre is the collector's work by Jože Karlovšek (1900–1963), a builder who has been diligently collecting a wide variety of ornamental materials throughout the Slovenian territory over 40 years. ”


Ethnologist prof. dr. Janez Bogataj PHOTO: Primoz Hieng

Already during his lifetime, Jože Karlovsek developed a duality about ornamentation, but he did not treat it separately, says Bogataj: “The first was a collector's goal, which is also a characteristic of all amateur collectors, and the second was of a more useful nature. Through numerous examples, he tried to show the usefulness of ornaments and other embellishing details in his new compositions, as applications on furniture, embroidery, in building equipment, various decorative objects and elsewhere. And it is in this second duality that the heritage of Jože Karlovšek's material is in perfect harmony with the collection of the RTA Agency, which offers a range of products with thoughtfully applied ornaments by the author. "


Cvetko's car is disguised as ornaments. PHOTO: Personal Archive

Looking at the many items from the Karlovšek collection now, one would think that it is merely a copy of what the collector has created. "So we are not talking about repeating historical memory or merely copying Karlovšek's ornaments, but about a thoughtful application that takes into account the diversity of materials, the form of objects and their usefulness and possible purposes," emphasizes prof. dr. Get rich. “The collection provides products in Slovenia that are recognizable precisely because of their selected ornaments. These are not only glued to the products, but are integral to the overall product structures. We can talk about the attribute that the ornamentation had in the periods that today represent our cultural heritage. "
